Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Multi-functional Near-field Scanning Optical Microscopy (NSOM) System to Establish a Cross-disciplinary Nano-imaging/spectroscopy Laboratory at CCNY
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award to City College of New York (CCNY) supports the acquisition of a state-of-the-art Near Field Scanning Optical Microscope (NSOM). NSOM is a critical and complementary nanoscopytechnique, which will immediately enable a wide range of important leading-edge, cross-disciplinary research projects at CCNY between the Chemistry, Physics, Chemical Engineering, Electrical Engineering and Biology departments. This multifunctional NSOM system will become a key component instrument of a "Nano-imaging/spectroscopy Laboratory" that will be established for use by a cluster of researchers who will comprise a so-called "Nanoscopy Cluster". The instrument will facilitate the acquisition of new knowledge, promote new experimental approaches, and promote cross-disciplinary collaborations. In addition, the instrument will be integrated into CCNY's "Shared Imaging Core Facility" and will create well-equipped research environments that integrate research with education of students, many of whom will be underrepresented minority students as CCNY is a recognized minority-serving institution. More than 20% of Ph.D. graduate students in the physical sciences and engineering would benefit from acquisition of the requested instrument. Undergraduate training and use of the tool will be integrated within the scope of the facilities goals, impacting multiple members of the large undergraduate research community at CCNY. In addition, through the non-profit organization, International Research Experiences, Inc. (iREs), NSOM techniques will be presented in a summer research program for high school students and teachers.

The goal is to establish a cross-disciplinary Nano-imaging/spectroscopy Laboratory at City College of New York (CCNY). The instrument will enable the pursuit of 16 research projects in highly diverse research areas/thrusts ranging from (1) Bio-inspired Self-assembled Nanomaterials, (2) Plasmonic & Photonic Materials, (3) Semiconductor Nanomaterials, (4) Natural Bio-Materials as well as (5) Materials for Frontier Applications. It will be used in answering a diverse set of both fundamental and applied scientific questions such as "nature of energy transport processes within and between nanoscale systems", "control of light-matter interaction in two-dimensional atomic crystals", "engineering melanin-derived polydopamine coatings and biosensors" as well as "development of high sensitivity Raman spectroscopy tools", and "understanding the failure modes in supercapacitors".

POR.DRECONTENT:
The beauty of nanoimaging techniques such as Near-field Scanning Optical Microscopy (NSOM) is that the results can be universally appreciated, by both technical and non-technical audiences. Objects or materials systems at the nanoscale—nanoobjects or nanostructured materials—are so small that they cannot be imaged (and thus investigated) even by the most advanced light-microscopes. The possibility to visualize or image nanostructured materials is not only a powerful research tool, it also has the incredible potential to create an enriching, inclusive experience to benefit public knowledge.

 

Intellectual Merit: Since becoming commercially available, NSOM has become an enabling method in diverse fields such as in nanoscience, structural biology, material science, photonics, and plasmonics. NSOM, a so-called “true” super high-resolution nanoscopy technique, uniquely combines high optical resolution (~50 nm) with high spatial resolution similar to Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), and complements comprehensively so-called “functional” super high-resolution nanoscopy techniques such as STORM, STEDM, or PALM. As with no other method, NSOM indeed uniquely allows researchers to address fundamental questions that require direct (simultaneous) correlation of structural/topographic information with optical information at the nanoscale. Therefore, this NSOM system immediately enabled research projects in highly diverse research areas/thrusts ranging from (1) Bio-inspired Self-assembled Nanomaterials, (2) Plasmonic & Photonic Materials, (3) Semiconductor Nanomaterials, (4) Natural Bio-Materials as well as (5) Materials for Frontier Applications. The instrument naturally facilitates the acquisition of new knowledge, as well as promotes new experimental approaches. Since the successful installation of the NSOM setup in May 2017, numerous collaborations have been enabled by this new instrument such as projects entitled “Bio-mimetic Antennae Systems for Light-Harvesting: Investigation of Frenkel Excitonic Properties of Light-Harvesting Nanotubes at the Nanoscale”, “Environmental Assisted Excitation-energy Transfer: Well-defined Bio-mimetic Scaffold for Artificial Supramolecular Light-Harvesting Antenna”, “Bio-mimetic Reaction Centers for Light-Harvesting: Investigation of Wannier Excitonic Properties of Semiconductor Quantum Dots (QDs) at the Nanoscale”, “DNA Nanotechnology for Light-harvesting: Characterization and Investigation of Novel DNA-Dye Hybrid Nanotubes at the Nanoscale”, or “Spectroscopic Characterization of Hierarchical Donor–Acceptor Supramolecular Polymers”. While first outcomes from these collaborative projects has been presented at international research conferences already, first research publications are expected starting in 2019.

 

Broader Impacts: Since 2005 the Science and Engineering programs at CCNY, the flagship campus of The City University of New York (CUNY), have benefited uniquely from the “Decade of Science” initiative, which has focused on both new laboratory construction/modernization and the hiring of new faculty. The new science research building opened in 2015: CCNY’s Center for Discovery and Innovation (CDI). This new science complex houses and fosters vibrant and innovative cross-disciplinary research projects addressing questions in diverse areas such as nanoscience, material science, photonics, neuroscience, structural biology, and environmental sensing. While facilities, such as NMR or TEM/CryoTEM, commonly for shared use, are available in the new complex, there was a clear need for nanoimaging/spectroscopy tools, such as NSOM. A state-of-the-art NSOM has been a critical and complementary nanoscopy technique at the CDI, which immediately enabled a wide range of leading-edge, cross-disciplinary research projects at CCNY between Chemistry, Physics, Chemical Engineering, Electrical Engineering and Biology. The purchased NSOM became a key component instrument of our "Nano-imaging/spectroscopy Laboratory" that has been established for use by a cluster of researchers who comprise a so-called "Nanoscopy Cluster". In general, the requested instrument will be integrated into CCNY’s ‘Shared Imaging Core Facility’ and will create well-equipped research environments that integrate research with education of students, many of whom will be underrepresented minority students since CCNY is a recognized minority-serving institution. We anticipate that more than 20% of Ph.D. graduate students in the physical sciences and engineering will benefit from the acquisition of the requested instrument. Recently, CCNY’s new science complex with its research facilities—including the here described NSOM system—has been highlighted in an outreach video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=loPazpG03DA&feature=youtu.be) produced by undergraduate students from CCNY. This video production was driven by the PI’s passion for educational outreach and the desire to promote science beyond academia and is part of the educational component of the PI’s 2018 NSF CAREER AWARD. This component aims to integrate fundamental research into educational outreach. The PI’s educational outreach projects focus on increasing the public’s awareness for fundamental research in Nanoscience for Solar Energy Harvesting and on contributing to increase the number of students choosing sciences and engineering as their career. The PI proposed to establish a Bi-weekly Interactive Science Afterschool Program (ISAP®) “Nanoscience: Big World of Very Small Things!” which has been developed in partnership with the local, non-profit organization CCNY’s The City Tutors. This program will engage middle-, high-school and CCNY undergraduate students as well as CCNY faculty in experiments performed in the PI’s nanoscience laboratory ranging from every-day experience to sophisticated nanoscopy training (nano-imaging via NSOM; leveraging this NSF funding). Specifically, ISAP will focus on children from minority groups living in the CCNY/Harlem community.
